name: Aquarius
backgroundOrigin: The Water Bearer. Represents Ganymede, a Trojan prince so beautiful that Zeus transformed into an eagle (Aquila) to abduct him. He became the cup-bearer on Mount Olympus. In Egypt, the jar was thought to cause the annual flooding of the Nile.
asterism: A "Y" shape (the Water Jar) flowing into faint lines.
majorStars: α (Sadalmelik), β (Sadalsuud), γ (Sadachbia), δ (Skat), ε (Albali), ζ, η, θ (Ancha), λ (Hydor)

name: Aries
backgroundOrigin: The Ram. The flying ram with the Golden Fleece. Sent by the cloud nymph Nephele to save her children, Phrixus and Helle. Phrixus sacrificed it to Zeus; its fleece later became the object of Jason and the Argonauts' quest.
asterism: A simple crooked line of 3 stars.
majorStars: α (Hamal), β (Sheratan), γ (Mesarthim), δ (Botein), ε, 41 Arietis

name: Cancer
backgroundOrigin: The Crab. Sent by Hera to pinch Hercules' toes and distract him while he fought the Hydra. Hercules crushed it. Grateful for its loyalty, Hera placed the crab in the stars.
asterism: An upside-down "Y" (very faint). Look for the "Beehive Cluster" in center.
majorStars: α (Acubens), β (Tarf), γ (Asellus Borealis), δ (Asellus Australis), ι

name: Capricornus
backgroundOrigin: The Sea Goat. Represents the god Pan. During a battle with the monster Typhon, Pan jumped into the Nile to escape. He transformed mid-jump, resulting in a creature with a goat's upper body and a fish's tail.
asterism: A large, triangular "bikini bottom" or wedge shape.
majorStars: α (Algedi), β (Dabih), γ (Nashira), δ (Deneb Algedi), ζ, ω, ψ

name: Gemini
backgroundOrigin: The Twins. Castor (mortal) and Pollux (immortal). When Castor died in battle, Pollux begged Zeus to let him share his immortality. Zeus placed them in the sky together. They are the patron saints of sailors.
asterism: Two parallel stick figures joined at the top (The Twins).
majorStars: α (Castor), β (Pollux), γ (Alhena), δ (Wasat), ε (Mebsuta), ζ (Mekbuda), η (Propus), μ (Tejat)

name: Leo
backgroundOrigin: The Lion. The Nemean Lion, a beast with impenetrable skin. Killing it was the first of Hercules' 12 Labors. Hercules strangled it and wore its pelt as armor.
asterism: A "Sickle" (backward question mark) head and a triangle body.
majorStars: α (Regulus), β (Denebola), γ (Algieba), δ (Zosma), ε (Rasalas), ζ (Adhafera), θ (Chertan), η, ο (Subra)

name: Libra
backgroundOrigin: The Scales. The only inanimate Zodiac sign. Romans viewed them as the Scales of Justice held by Virgo (Astraea). Greeks originally saw them as the "Claws" of the Scorpion.
asterism: A diamond or box shape (formerly Scorpion's claws).
majorStars: α (Zubenelgenubi), β (Zubeneschamali), γ (Zubenelhakrabi), σ (Brachium), τ, υ

name: Pisces
backgroundOrigin: The Fish. Aphrodite and her son Eros tied themselves together with a cord and turned into fish to escape the monster Typhon via the river Euphrates.
asterism: A "V" shape connecting two circles (the fish).
majorStars: α (Alrescha), β (Fumalsamakah), γ, δ, ε, ζ, η (Alpherg), ω, ι

name: Sagittarius
backgroundOrigin: The Archer. Usually Crotus, a satyr who invented the bow (distinct from Chiron). He keeps his arrow aimed at the heart of the Scorpion (Antares) to avenge Orion.
asterism: The "Teapot" asterism (spout, lid, and handle).
majorStars: α (Rukbat), β (Arkab), γ (Alnasl), δ (Kaus Media), ε (Kaus Australis), ζ (Ascella), λ (Kaus Borealis), σ (Nunki)

name: Scorpius
backgroundOrigin: The Scorpion. A giant scorpion sent by Gaia (Earth) to kill the hunter Orion for his arrogance. They were placed on opposite sides of the sky so they never appear together.
asterism: A large "J" or hook shape; looks exactly like a scorpion.
majorStars: α (Antares), β (Acrab), δ (Dschubba), ε (Larawag), θ (Sargas), ι, κ (Girtab), λ (Shaula), υ (Lesath)

name: Taurus
backgroundOrigin: The Bull. Zeus in disguise as a white bull to abduct Princess Europa. He swam her across the sea to Crete; the constellation shows only the front half as his rear is "submerged."
asterism: A "V" shape (Hyades cluster) and the Pleiades cluster nearby.
majorStars: α (Aldebaran), β (Elnath), γ (Prima Hyadum), ε (Ain), ζ (Tianguan), η (Alcyone), Pleiades Cluster

name: Virgo
backgroundOrigin: The Virgin. Dike (Justice) or Demeter (Harvest). She holds a stalk of wheat (Spica). She was the last deity to leave Earth when the Golden Age of mankind ended.
asterism: A "Y" shape or a reclining figure holding a stalk of wheat.
majorStars: α (Spica), β (Zavijava), γ (Porrima), δ (Auva), ε (Vindemiatrix), ζ (Heze), η (Zaniah), ι (Syrma)

name: Boötes
backgroundOrigin: The Herdsman. The bear driver. In some myths, he is Arcas, the son of Callisto, who was placed in the sky to prevent him from accidentally hunting his mother (the Bear).
asterism: A giant Kite or Ice Cream Cone shape.
majorStars: α (Arcturus), β (Nekkar), γ (Seginus), δ, ε (Izar), η (Muphrid), ρ, ζ

name: Camelopardalis
backgroundOrigin: The Giraffe. Created by Petrus Plancius (1612) to fill the gap between Auriga and the Bears. Represents the camel/giraffe Rebecca rode to meet Isaac in the Bible.
asterism: Large but very faint sprawling zig-zag.
majorStars: α, β, 7 Cam, BK Cam, BE Cam (Very faint, no named stars)

name: Canes Venatici
backgroundOrigin: The Hunting Dogs. Introduced by Hevelius (1687). The dogs Asterion and Chara, held on a leash by Boötes to chase the Great Bear around the pole.
asterism: A simple line of two bright stars under the Big Dipper handle.
majorStars: α (Cor Caroli), β (Chara)

name: Coma Berenices
backgroundOrigin: Berenice's Hair. Queen Berenice II sacrificed her long hair for her husband's safe return from war. The court astronomer Conon claimed the missing hair had been placed among the stars by the gods.
asterism: A right-angle hook; looks like a shimmering cluster of faint stars.
majorStars: α (Diadem), β, γ
source: Tycho Brahe (Ancient asterism, formalized by Brahe)

name: Corona Borealis
backgroundOrigin: The Northern Crown. The golden crown of Princess Ariadne. After Theseus abandoned her, Dionysus married her and threw her crown into the sky.
asterism: A distinct "C" or bowl shape (The Crown).
majorStars: α (Alphecca), β (Nusakan), γ, δ, ε, θ, ι

name: Draco
backgroundOrigin: The Dragon. Ladon, the dragon that guarded the golden apples of the Hesperides. Slain by Hercules. It circles the North Pole, representing the dragon that "never sleeps."
asterism: A long snake winding between the Bears; ends in a "Lozenge" head.
majorStars: α (Thuban), β (Rastaban), γ (Eltanin), δ (Altais), ζ (Aldhibah), η (Aldhibain), ι (Edasich)

name: Leo Minor
backgroundOrigin: The Little Lion. A "filler" constellation created by Hevelius (1687) simply because he felt the King of Beasts (Leo) should not have empty space nearby.
asterism: A faint, flat triangle between Leo and Ursa Major.
majorStars: 46 Leonis Minoris (Praecipua), β, 21 LMi

name: Lynx
backgroundOrigin: The Lynx. Created by Hevelius (1687). It is so faint that he joked one would need "the eyes of a lynx" to see it.
asterism: A faint, zig-zag line. Hard to see.
majorStars: α, 38 Lyncis (Maculosa), 31 Lyncis (Alsciaukat)

name: Ursa Major
backgroundOrigin: The Great Bear. Callisto, a nymph turned into a bear by a jealous Hera. To save her from being hunted, Zeus grabbed her by the tail (stretching it) and flung her into the sky.
asterism: Contains the "Big Dipper" (Plough) asterism.
majorStars: α (Dubhe), β (Merak), γ (Phecda), δ (Megrez), ε (Alioth), ζ (Mizar), η (Alkaid), 80 UMa (Alcor)

name: Ursa Minor
backgroundOrigin: The Little Bear. Arcas, son of Callisto. Transformed into a bear by Zeus to remain with his mother. Hera cursed them to circle the pole forever, never resting in the ocean.
asterism: The "Little Dipper" (fainter, curved handle).
majorStars: α (Polaris), β (Kochab), γ (Pherkad), δ (Yildun), ε, ζ, η

name: Andromeda
backgroundOrigin: The Chained Princess. Daughter of Cassiopeia. Chained to a rock as a sacrifice to the sea monster Cetus to appease Poseidon; saved by Perseus.
asterism: A V-shape or line extending from the Great Square of Pegasus.
majorStars: α (Alpheratz), β (Mirach), γ (Almach), δ, 51 And, μ, ν

name: Auriga
backgroundOrigin: The Charioteer. Erichthonius, King of Athens, who invented the four-horse chariot to overcome his lameness. Zeus admired his ingenuity.
asterism: An irregular pentagon (diamond shape).
majorStars: α (Capella), β (Menkalinan), θ (Mahasim), ι (Hassaleh), ε (Almaaz), ζ (Saclateni), η (Haedus)

name: Cassiopeia
backgroundOrigin: The Queen. The vain Queen of Ethiopia who boasted she was fairer than the sea nymphs. Punished by being tied to her throne and hung upside down in the sky.
asterism: A distinct "W" or "M" shape (depending on orientation).
majorStars: α (Schedar), β (Caph), γ (Navi), δ (Ruchbah), ε (Segin), η (Achird)

name: Cepheus
backgroundOrigin: The King. King of Ethiopia, husband of Cassiopeia. Forced to sacrifice his daughter to save his kingdom. Depicted as a stern monarch in robes.
asterism: A house shape (square with a triangle roof).
majorStars: α (Alderamin), β (Alfirk), γ (Errai), ζ, ι, μ (Garnet Star)

name: Cetus
backgroundOrigin: The Sea Monster. The beast sent by Poseidon to devour Andromeda. Perseus turned it to stone using Medusa's severed head.
asterism: A large whale body with a circle for the head (the Monster's Maw).
majorStars: α (Menkar), β (Diphda), γ (Kaffaljidhma), ζ (Baten Kaitos), τ, ο (Mira)

name: Lacerta
backgroundOrigin: The Lizard. Created by Hevelius (1687) to fill a small, starless gap between Andromeda and Cygnus.
asterism: A zig-zag "W" shape (often called Little Cassiopeia).
majorStars: α, β, 1 through 6 Lacertae

name: Pegasus
backgroundOrigin: The Winged Horse. Sprang from the neck of Medusa when Perseus beheaded her. Later the mount of Bellerophon.
asterism: The "Great Square" (a large, empty box of stars).
majorStars: α (Markab), β (Scheat), γ (Algenib), ε (Enif), ζ (Homam), η (Matar), θ (Biham), μ (Sadalbari)

name: Perseus
backgroundOrigin: The Hero. Son of Zeus. He slew Medusa and saved Andromeda. Depicted holding the demon's head (Algol) and a sword.
asterism: A wishbone or forked line of stars.
majorStars: α (Mirfak), β (Algol), ζ (Atik), ε, δ, γ, ρ (Gorgonea Tertia)

name: Triangulum
backgroundOrigin: The Triangle. An ancient constellation representing the Greek letter Delta (Δ), symbolizing the Nile Delta.
asterism: A long, narrow triangle.
majorStars: α (Mothallah), β (Deltoton), γ

name: Aquila
backgroundOrigin: The Eagle. The bird that carried Zeus's thunderbolts and tortured Prometheus. Hercules killed it with an arrow.
asterism: A diamond or flying bird shape along the Milky Way.
majorStars: α (Altair), β (Alshain), γ (Tarazed), δ, ε, ζ (Okab), η, θ, λ (Al Thalimain)

name: Ara
backgroundOrigin: The Altar. The altar where the gods swore a pact of allegiance before battling the Titans.
asterism: An "H" shape or twisted box beneath Scorpius.
majorStars: α, β, γ, δ, ζ, η, ε

name: Centaurus
backgroundOrigin: The Centaur. Chiron, the wise tutor of Hercules and Jason. Accidentally poisoned by Hercules, he traded his immortality to escape the pain.
asterism: Large, bright hexagon arching over the Southern Cross.
majorStars: α (Rigil Kentaurus), β (Hadar), θ (Menkent), γ (Muhlifain), ε, η, ζ

name: Corona Australis
backgroundOrigin: The Southern Crown. A wreath worn by the Centaur, or the crown placed in the sky by Dionysus to honor his mother Semele.
asterism: An arc or semi-circle of stars (The Wreath).
majorStars: α (Meridiana), β, γ, δ, ε

name: Corvus
backgroundOrigin: The Crow. Apollo's bird. It lied about why it was late fetching water (blaming a snake). Apollo banished it to the sky, placing the water cup (Crater) just out of reach.
asterism: A distinct trapezoid (The Sail) appearing to "ride" Hydra.
majorStars: α (Alchiba), β (Kraz), γ (Gienah), δ (Algorab), ε (Minkar)

name: Crater
backgroundOrigin: The Cup. The chalice of Apollo carried by the Crow.
asterism: A faint cup or goblet shape.
majorStars: α (Alkes), β, γ, δ (Labrum), ε, ζ

name: Crux
backgroundOrigin: The Southern Cross. Originally part of the Centaur's legs. Separated by 16th-century navigators to serve as a vital tool for finding the South Pole.
asterism: A tight, bright cross (The Southern Cross).
majorStars: α (Acrux), β (Mimosa), γ (Gacrux), δ (Imai), ε (Ginan)

name: Cygnus
backgroundOrigin: The Swan. Zeus disguised as a swan to seduce Leda. Also associated with Orpheus, placed near his lyre.
asterism: A large cross (The Northern Cross) flying down the Milky Way.
majorStars: α (Deneb), β (Albireo), γ (Sadr), δ (Fawaris), ε (Aljanah), ζ, τ

name: Hercules
backgroundOrigin: The Kneeler. The greatest Greek hero, shown kneeling with his foot on the Dragon's head. Famous for his 12 Labors.
asterism: A central "Keystone" (trapezoid) with limbs extending out.
majorStars: α (Rasalgethi), β (Kornephoros), ζ, δ (Sarin), π, η, ε, μ

name: Hydra
backgroundOrigin: The Water Snake. The multi-headed beast of Lerna slain by Hercules. When one head was cut, two grew back.
asterism: A long, winding snake spanning 100 degrees of sky.
majorStars: α (Alphard), γ, ζ, ν, π, ε, xi, β

name: Lupus
backgroundOrigin: The Wolf. An undefined beast being speared by the Centaur and offered as a sacrifice on the Altar.
asterism: A distinctive asterism of bright stars near Centaurus.
majorStars: α, β, γ, δ, ε, ζ, η, ι

name: Lyra
backgroundOrigin: The Lyre. The harp of Orpheus. It produced music that could charm stones. Placed in the sky by Zeus after Orpheus died.
asterism: A small parallelogram attached to a bright star.
majorStars: α (Vega), β (Sheliak), γ (Sulafat), δ, ε (Double Double), ζ, η (Aladfar)

name: Ophiuchus
backgroundOrigin: The Serpent Bearer. Asclepius, the god of medicine. He holds the snake (Serpens), representing the renewal of life (shedding skin).
asterism: A large, house-shaped bell curve holding the Serpent.
majorStars: α (Rasalhague), η (Sabik), ζ (Han), δ (Yed Prior), ε (Yed Posterior), β (Cebalrai), κ

name: Sagitta
backgroundOrigin: The Arrow. The arrow Hercules used to kill the eagle Aquila.
asterism: A clear, small arrow shape.
majorStars: α (Sham), β, γ, δ

name: Scutum
backgroundOrigin: The Shield. Created by Hevelius (1684) to honor King Jan III Sobieski of Poland for defending Europe at the Battle of Vienna.
asterism: Small diamond shape in the Milky Way rift.
majorStars: α, β, γ, δ

name: Serpens Cauda
backgroundOrigin: The Serpent. The snake held by Ophiuchus. Unique for being split into two separate parts (Head and Tail).
asterism: Two parts (Head and Tail) on either side of Ophiuchus.
majorStars: α (Unukalhai), η, μ, ξ, ε, δ, γ, θ (Alya)

name: Serpens Caput
backgroundOrigin: The Serpent. The snake held by Ophiuchus. Unique for being split into two separate parts (Head and Tail).
asterism: Two parts (Head and Tail) on either side of Ophiuchus.
majorStars: α (Unukalhai), η, μ, ξ, ε, δ, γ, θ (Alya)

name: Sextans
backgroundOrigin: The Sextant. Created by Hevelius (1687) to commemorate the astronomical instrument he used to measure stars.
asterism: Faint, irregular box.
majorStars: α, β, γ

name: Triangulum Aust.
backgroundOrigin: The Southern Triangle. A navigational constellation created by Plancius (1589) to mark the southern skies.
asterism: A distinct, bright equilateral triangle.
majorStars: α (Atria), β, γ
source: Petrus Plancius (Based on Keyser/de Houtman data)

name: Vulpecula
backgroundOrigin: The Fox. Created by Hevelius. Originally "The Little Fox with the Goose."
asterism: Faint line; inside the Summer Triangle.
majorStars: α (Anser), 23 Vulpeculae, 13 Vulpeculae

name: Canis Major
backgroundOrigin: The Great Dog. Orion's main hunting dog. Contains Sirius. Greeks believed its rising caused the heat of summer ("Dog Days").
asterism: A stick figure dog standing on hind legs.
majorStars: α (Sirius), ε (Adhara), δ (Wezen), β (Mirzam), η (Aludra), ζ (Furud), ο 1 & 2

name: Canis Minor
backgroundOrigin: The Little Dog. Orion's second dog. Also identified as Maera, the loyal dog of Erigone.
asterism: A simple line of two stars.
majorStars: α (Procyon), β (Gomeisa)

name: Lepus
backgroundOrigin: The Hare. A rabbit placed at Orion's feet, eternally chased by his dogs. Placed in the sky by Hermes for its speed.
asterism: An "H" or box shape under Orion's feet.
majorStars: α (Arneb), β (Nihal), γ, δ, ε, μ, ζ

name: Monoceros
backgroundOrigin: The Unicorn. Created by Plancius (1612) to fill the void between the two dogs. References the biblical unicorn.
asterism: Faint shape inside the "Winter Triangle" stars.
majorStars: α, β (Wonder Star), γ, δ

name: Orion
backgroundOrigin: The Hunter. A giant, arrogant hunter who threatened to kill every beast on Earth. Slain by a scorpion sent by Gaia.
asterism: Distinct hourglass; 3 Belt stars, sword hangs from belt.
majorStars: α (Betelgeuse), β (Rigel), γ (Bellatrix), δ (Mintaka), ε (Alnilam), ζ (Alnitak), κ (Saiph), λ (Meissa)

name: Carina
backgroundOrigin: The Keel. The hull of Argo Navis, the ship of Jason and the Argonauts. Separated from the giant ship constellation in the 18th century.
asterism: The base of a ship; bright and dense.
majorStars: α (Canopus), β (Miaplacidus), ε (Avior), ι (Aspidiske), θ, υ, ω
source: Nicolas Louis de Lacaille (Split ancient Argo Navis)

name: Columba
backgroundOrigin: The Dove. The bird Noah released from the Ark, or the dove the Argonauts released to pass the Clashing Rocks.
asterism: A crooked line or small quadrilateral south of Orion.
majorStars: α (Phact), β (Wazn), γ, δ

name: Delphinus
backgroundOrigin: The Dolphin. The messenger of Poseidon who found Amphitrite and convinced her to marry the sea god.
asterism: A small, distinct diamond with a tail (The Job's Coffin).
majorStars: α (Sualocin), β (Rotanev), γ, δ, ε (Deneb Dulfim)

name: Equuleus
backgroundOrigin: The Little Horse. Celeris, the brother of Pegasus. A small "head-only" horse rising before Pegasus.
asterism: A faint, small trapezoid near Pegasus.
majorStars: α (Kitalpha), β, γ, δ

name: Eridanus
backgroundOrigin: The River. The celestial river. Phaethon fell into it after crashing the Sun Chariot.
asterism: A long, winding river of stars starting at Orion's foot.
majorStars: α (Achernar), β (Cursa), γ (Zaurak), δ (Rana), ε (Sadira), θ (Acamar)

name: Piscis Austrinus
backgroundOrigin: The Southern Fish. The parent of the Pisces fish. Seen drinking water from Aquarius's jar.
asterism: A flattened oval or loop.
majorStars: α (Fomalhaut), β, γ, δ, ε

name: Puppis
backgroundOrigin: The Stern. The rear deck of Argo Navis. Contains the star Naos ("Ship").
asterism: Dense collection of bright stars (the Ship's Deck).
majorStars: ζ (Naos), π (Ahadi), ρ (Tureis), τ, ν, σ, ξ (Azmidi)
source: Nicolas Louis de Lacaille (Split ancient Argo Navis)

name: Pyxis
backgroundOrigin: The Compass. The mariner's compass of Argo Navis. Renamed by Lacaille to add a navigational tool to the ship.
asterism: A faint line of three stars.
majorStars: α, β, γ
source: Nicolas Louis de Lacaille (Added to Argo Navis split)

name: Vela
backgroundOrigin: The Sails. The sails of Argo Navis. Contains the "False Cross" asterism.
asterism: A complex ring or cross of stars (The False Cross).
majorStars: γ (Regor), δ (Alsephina), λ (Suhail), κ (Markeb), μ, φ, ψ
source: Nicolas Louis de Lacaille (Split ancient Argo Navis)

name: Apus
backgroundOrigin: The Bird of Paradise. "No Feet" (Greek). Sailors believed these birds never landed and had no feet.
asterism: Faint triangle near the South Pole.
majorStars: α, β, γ, δ
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Chamaeleon
backgroundOrigin: The Chameleon. Named after the color-changing lizard seen by Dutch sailors in the East Indies.
asterism: Small diamond shape near the South Celestial Pole.
majorStars: α, β, γ, δ
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Dorado
backgroundOrigin: The Dolphinfish. Represents the Mahi-Mahi (golden fish) chasing the Flying Fish.
asterism: A faint vertical line; look for the Large Magellanic Cloud nearby.
majorStars: α, β, γ, δ
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Grus
backgroundOrigin: The Crane. Created from stars originally belonging to the Southern Fish. Represents the wading birds of the south.
asterism: A distinct, bright bird-like cross.
majorStars: α (Alnair), β (Tiaki), γ (Aldhanab), δ, ε, ζ
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Hydrus
backgroundOrigin: The Male Water Snake. The southern counterpart to Hydra. Represents sea snakes of the Indian Ocean.
asterism: A triangle near the Magellanic Clouds.
majorStars: α, β, γ
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Indus
backgroundOrigin: The Indian. Represents the indigenous peoples encountered by explorers in the East Indies and Africa.
asterism: A faint triangle or bent line.
majorStars: α (The Persian), β, ε
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Musca
backgroundOrigin: The Fly. Originally "The Bee." Renamed to avoid confusion with Apus. Prey of the Chameleon.
asterism: A clear trapezoid south of the Southern Cross.
majorStars: α, β, γ, δ
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Pavo
backgroundOrigin: The Peacock. Named after the Green Peafowl of Java. Also references the Greek myth of Argus's 100 eyes.
asterism: A "saucepan" shape (similar to Big Dipper but southern).
majorStars: α (Peacock), β, δ, η, ε
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Phoenix
backgroundOrigin: The Phoenix. The mythical firebird reborn from ashes. Symbolized the "torrid" southern zones.
asterism: A tilted boat or irregular triangle shape.
majorStars: α (Ankaa), β, γ, ε, δ, ζ
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Tucana
backgroundOrigin: The Toucan. Named after the South American bird. Home to the Small Magellanic Cloud.
asterism: A kite shape; home to the star cluster 47 Tucanae.
majorStars: α, γ, ζ, β
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Volans
backgroundOrigin: The Flying Fish. Fish seen gliding over the ocean by sailors to escape predators.
asterism: An irregular trapezoid or kite.
majorStars: β, γ, ζ, δ, α, ε
source: Keyser & de Houtman (First published by Bayer 1603)

name: Antlia
backgroundOrigin: The Air Pump. Honors the invention of the pneumatic air pump by Boyle and Papin.
asterism: Very faint; irregular pattern. Hard to spot.
majorStars: α, ε, ι, θ

name: Caelum
backgroundOrigin: The Chisel. Represents the engraver's tools used to create copperplate prints (and star maps).
asterism: Faint line; no distinct shape.
majorStars: α, γ, β

name: Circinus
backgroundOrigin: The Drafting Compass. The tool used by cartographers and architects to draw circles.
asterism: A narrow triangle pointing toward Alpha Centauri.
majorStars: α, β, γ

name: Fornax
backgroundOrigin: The Furnace. The chemist's (alchemist's) distillation furnace.
asterism: Faint, amorphous shape.
majorStars: α (Dalim), β

name: Horologium
backgroundOrigin: The Clock. Honors Christiaan Huygens' invention of the pendulum clock.
asterism: Very faint, bent line.
majorStars: α, δ, β

name: Mensa
backgroundOrigin: Table Mountain. Honors Mons Mensa in South Africa, where Lacaille conducted his observations.
asterism: The faintest constellation; difficult to see even in dark skies.
majorStars: α, γ, β (Very faint)

name: Microscopium
backgroundOrigin: The Microscope. Honors the invention of the compound microscope.
asterism: Faint; no distinct shape.
majorStars: γ, ε, α

name: Norma
backgroundOrigin: The Carpenter's Square. Represents a level, ruler, and square used in construction.
asterism: Faint box shape in the Milky Way.
majorStars: γ2, η, ε

name: Octans
backgroundOrigin: The Octant. Navigational instrument invented by John Hadley. Marks the South Celestial Pole.
asterism: Faint triangle; marks the South Celestial Pole (no bright pole star).
majorStars: ν, β, δ, θ, σ (Polaris Australis)

name: Pictor
backgroundOrigin: The Easel. Represents a painter's easel and palette.
asterism: Faint; located near the bright star Canopus.
majorStars: α, β, γ

name: Reticulum
backgroundOrigin: The Reticle. The crosshairs in a telescope eyepiece used to measure star positions.
asterism: A distinct, small diamond shape.
majorStars: α, β, ε, γ, δ

name: Sculptor
backgroundOrigin: The Sculptor. Represents a sculptor's studio with a carved head and mallet.
asterism: Faint; contains the South Galactic Pole.
majorStars: α, β, γ, δ

name: Telescopium
backgroundOrigin: The Telescope. Honors the invention of the refracting telescope.
asterism: Faint stars forming a corner shape.
majorStars: α, ζ, ε
